overview: From 2025-11-01 to 2025-12-01, ethereum-optimism/specs had 14 new PRs (14 merged), 0 new issues, and 62 active contributors.

We should remove the specs for the included contracts and put them into an `experimental/liquidity-migration.md` file

topPRs.title: docs(specs/experimental/contracts): create FaultDisputeGame specification
topPRs.author: devin-ai-integration
topPRs.body:
# Create comprehensive FaultDisputeGame specification covering all variants

## Summary

Created a new contract specification for the FaultDisputeGame family at `specs/experimental/contracts/dispute/fault-dispute-game.md`. This specification covers five contract variants that share the core bisection-based dispute resolution mechanism but differ in access control and architectural implementation:

- **FaultDisputeGame**: Base permissionless V1 implementation
- **PermissionedDisputeGame**: Permissioned V1 with proposer/challenger roles
- **SuperPermissionedDisputeGame**: Permissioned variant extending SuperFaultDisputeGame
- **FaultDisputeGameV2**: Permissionless V2 using Immutable Args Pattern
- **PermissionedDisputeGameV2**: Permissioned V2 with Immutable Args Pattern

The specification includes:
- Overview and Contract Variants sections explaining the family
- 9 Definitions (including Proposer Role, Challenger Role, Immutable Args Pattern)
- 3 Assumptions about external dependencies (AnchorStateRegistry, VM, DelayedWETH)
- 7 Invariants including new i01-007 for permissioned access control
- Complete function specifications for 30+ public/external functions

## Review & Testing Checklist for Human

- [ ] **Verify multi-variant approach**: Confirm that documenting all 5 variants in a single specification (rather than separate specs) aligns with documentation standards and makes sense for maintainability
- [ ] **Cross-check permission model**: Review invariant i01-007 and the permission-related updates to `initialize()`, `step()`, and `move()` functions against actual contract code to ensure accuracy, especially the distinction between which variants have which restrictions
- [ ] **Validate V2 architectural changes**: Check that the Immutable Args Pattern definition and V2-specific behaviors (especially in `initialize()` with variable calldata length) accurately reflect the architectural refactoring
- [ ] **Review invariants for completeness**: Verify that the 7 invariants capture all critical cross-function security properties, particularly around game resolution, bond distribution, and access control
- [ ] **Spot-check function behaviors**: Select 3-5 critical functions (e.g., `resolveClaim`, `closeGame`, `challengeRootL2Block`) and verify their MUST/MUST NOT requirements match actual contract implementation

### Notes

This specification was created entirely from code analysis without ability to test against actual deployments. The spec attempts to be comprehensive but may have missed subtle edge cases or variant-specific behaviors that aren't immediately obvious from code reading alone. Pay particular attention to areas where behavior differs between variants (especially V1 vs V2 and permissioned vs permissionless).

**Session**: https://app.devin.ai/sessions/5f4083160bbf44b5bf07eb21550b9af7  
**Requested by**: Ariel Diaz (ariel@oplabs.co) / @aliersh

topPRs.title: docs(specs/experimental/contracts): create GovernanceToken specification
topPRs.author: devin-ai-integration
topPRs.body:
# docs(specs/experimental/contracts): create GovernanceToken specification

## Summary

Created a comprehensive specification for the GovernanceToken contract following the canonical format. The spec documents the ERC20 governance token with voting/delegation capabilities (ERC20Votes) and controlled minting through the MintManager owner. Key sections include:

- **Overview**: High-level description of the token's role in OP Stack governance
- **Assumptions**: Owner governance constraints and ERC20Votes supply limits
- **Invariants**: 3 invariants covering voting power accuracy, transfer freedom, and minting authorization
- **Function Specification**: Complete documentation of all public/external functions including mint, burn/burnFrom, delegation (delegate, delegateBySig), voting queries (getVotes, getPastVotes, etc.), and standard ERC20/ERC20Permit functions

The spec is based on the actual contract implementation at `packages/contracts-bedrock/src/governance/GovernanceToken.sol`, which is a straightforward composition of OpenZeppelin contracts (ERC20Burnable, ERC20Votes, Ownable) with a custom owner-only mint function.

**Note**: An experimental spec existed at `/specs/experimental/gov-token.md` describing GovernanceDelegation integration, but this was NOT implemented in the actual contract, so I based this spec on the simpler `/specs/governance/gov-token.md` and the actual contract code.

## Review & Testing Checklist for Human

- [ ] **Verify inherited function behaviors are accurate**: The spec documents behavior from OpenZeppelin's ERC20Votes, ERC20Permit, and ERC20Burnable. Spot-check that documented behaviors (especially voting power updates, delegation mechanics, and signature validation) match the actual OpenZeppelin implementations used by the contract.

- [ ] **Review invariant classification**: Particularly iGT-003 ("Unauthorized minting is impossible") - confirm this is appropriate as an invariant rather than just being in the mint() function spec. The guidelines allow critical security properties in either location, but worth double-checking.

- [ ] **Validate assumptions are true external dependencies**: Especially aGT-002 about the ERC20Votes total supply constraint - is this really an "assumption" (external dependency) or just a technical limitation of the inherited implementation?

- [ ] **Confirm no experimental features were included**: The experimental spec at `/specs/experimental/gov-token.md` describes GovernanceDelegation hook integration that doesn't exist in the actual contract. Verify this spec correctly documents only what's actually implemented.

### Notes

- All lint checks passed (markdown, TOC, spelling, filenames)
- Excluded `version()` function from spec as per guidelines (standard ISemver)
- Used N/A for Definitions since all terms are standard ERC20/voting concepts
- Placed spec at `/specs/experimental/contracts/governance/governance-token.md` following the path mapping rules

**Session**: https://app.devin.ai/sessions/85e0ab1d881c4a94b1ee4d43614b20f3  
**Requested by**: Ariel Diaz (ariel@oplabs.co), GitHub: @aliersh

topPRs.title: feat: L2CM specs
topPRs.author: 0xiamflux
topPRs.body:
Add specifications for the `L2ContractsManager` project. These enable deterministic hard fork upgrades of L2 predeploys.

- **L2ProxyAdmin**: L2-specific implementation of universal `ProxyAdmin` with `upgradePredeploys()` and ERC1967-only overrides
- **L2ContractsManager**: Orchestrates predeploy upgrades, deployed per hard fork as part of NUT bundles
- **ConditionalDeployer**: A wrapper around the `Create2Deployer` predeploy, allowing for non-reverting deterministic deployments in case of address collision.
- **TransactionGenerationScript**: A periphery contract that generates Network Upgrade Bundles for its execution during hard forks.

Includes invariants, assumptions, function specifications, and security considerations.

[Design document](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs/pull/351)

topPRs.title: Link defined terms to their definitions throughout contract specs
topPRs.author: devin-ai-integration
topPRs.body:
# Link defined terms to their definitions throughout contract specs

## Summary

Added markdown links for all defined terms throughout the contract specification documents in `specs/experimental/contracts/`. When a term is defined in a document's "Definitions" section, all occurrences of that term throughout the document are now linked to the definition using markdown syntax `[Term Name](#anchor-link)`.

**Files modified**: 20 markdown files across L1, L2, cannon, dispute, safe, and universal directories

**Examples of changes**:
- "authorized portal" â†’ "[Authorized Portal](#authorized-portal)"
- "message hash" â†’ "[Message Hash](#message-hash)"  
- "admin" â†’ "[Admin](#admin)"
- Plural forms handled correctly: "authorized portals" â†’ "[Authorized Portals](#authorized-portal)"

**Implementation approach**: Used Python scripts to systematically process each file, identifying defined terms and linking occurrences while avoiding code blocks, the Definitions section itself, and the auto-generated TOC. Line lengths were automatically wrapped to comply with markdown linting rules, and TOCs were regenerated to reflect the changes.

## Review & Testing Checklist for Human

**Risk level**: ðŸŸ¡ Yellow (automated changes across many files with limited testing)

- [ ] **Spot-check link correctness**: Open 3-4 modified files and click several term links to verify they navigate to the correct definition anchor
- [ ] **Verify no over-linking**: Check that terms inside backticks (like `_admin` parameters), code blocks, and function names were NOT linked
- [ ] **Check line wrapping**: Review files with many wrapped lines (proxy.md, fault-dispute-game.md, preimage-oracle.md) to ensure readability wasn't compromised
- [ ] **Test rendered docs**: Run `just serve` locally and navigate through several spec files to verify the links work in the rendered documentation

### Test Plan
```bash
# Build and serve the documentation locally
cd ~/repos/specs
just serve

# Navigate to http://localhost:3000
# Open several contract specs and:
# 1. Click on linked terms to verify they jump to the definition
# 2. Verify terms are capitalized correctly
# 3. Check that code examples still look correct
```

### Notes
- The automated approach means if there's a bug in the link logic, it could be replicated across multiple files - thorough spot-checking is important
- Some section headings may have had their terms capitalized (e.g., "non-admin" â†’ "non-Admin") but not linked, which could appear inconsistent
- Line wrapping was done automatically to pass lint checks; some paragraphs may flow differently than before

**Link to Devin run**: https://app.devin.ai/sessions/ce41c51fd75d474b90b2b200b3b95fc9  
**Requested by**: Ariel Diaz (ariel@oplabs.co), @aliersh

topPRs.title: docs(specs/experimental/contracts): create MIPS64 specification
topPRs.author: devin-ai-integration
topPRs.body:
# docs(specs/experimental/contracts): create MIPS64 specification

## Summary

This PR adds a comprehensive specification for the MIPS64 contract (`packages/contracts-bedrock/src/cannon/MIPS64.sol`), which is the on-chain MIPS64 virtual machine emulator used in the Cannon fault proof system.

**Key components documented:**
- Overview explaining the contract's role in fault proof verification
- Definitions for thread stack, memory reservation, context switch, and state version concepts
- Two assumptions about external dependencies (PreimageOracle and proof data)
- Four invariants covering thread stack integrity, memory reservation atomicity, hash consistency, and determinism
- Function specifications for `step()`, `oracle()`, and `stateVersion()` functions

## Review & Testing Checklist for Human

This PR is documentation only and cannot be tested in isolation. Please validate the specification against the actual contract implementation:

- [ ] **Verify invariants are accurate**: Review each of the 4 invariants (i01-001 through i01-004) against the MIPS64 contract code to ensure they are actually maintained across all functions. Pay special attention to thread stack management and memory reservation logic.

- [ ] **Check function specifications completeness**: The `step()` function has complex behavior (syscalls, threading, RMW operations). Verify that all critical behaviors are documented and no edge cases are missing. Cross-reference with the contract code at lines 126-288.

- [ ] **Validate assumptions**: Confirm that the two assumptions (PreimageOracle validity and proof data well-formedness) capture all critical external dependencies. Are there other contracts or systems this contract depends on?

- [ ] **Review definitions accuracy**: Verify that the definitions (especially Thread Stack and Memory Reservation) accurately describe the mechanisms used in the contract. Check that the link to the Cannon VM spec works and is appropriate.

- [ ] **Check for missing invariants**: The contract has complex multithreading logic. Are there other cross-function properties that should be documented as invariants (e.g., related to state versions, step counters, or preemption)?

### Notes

- This specification was created by analyzing the MIPS64 contract source code
- All linting checks passed (markdown, TOC, spelling)
- The spec follows the canonical format for contract specifications in the OP Stack
- Link to Devin run: https://app.devin.ai/sessions/09a707f4ca8940ee8180dbef97af6448
- Requested by: Ariel Diaz (ariel@oplabs.co) @aliersh

topContributors.summary: sbvegan: Focused on critical documentation and registry updates, merging 12 PRs to support network communications and upgrades. They executed a major update to notice pages for communications in `ethereum-optimism/docs#1847` (+2155/-698 lines) and managed key details for the Jovian hard fork, including updating release information in `ethereum-optimism/docs#1852`. In addition to these direct contributions, sbvegan was an active collaborator, providing 25 code reviews. This work shows a primary focus on maintaining and improving project documentation.

devin-ai-integration: Focused on improving the quality and clarity of documentation and contract specifications for the Ethereum Optimism project. They made several impactful enhancements to the specifications, most notably by linking defined terms to their definitions in a large refactor (`specs#856`, +274/-225 lines), adding a new `SuperFaultDisputeGame` variant (`specs#852`), and cleaning up existing contract specs (`specs#853`, `specs#854`). This was complemented by a broad effort across 12 separate pull requests to fix typos and grammatical errors throughout the `ethereum-optimism/docs` repository, demonstrating a clear focus on improving overall documentation and specification quality.

ajsutton: Focused on supporting the team through collaboration this month. They contributed to project progress by providing 3 pull request reviews, which included 2 approvals. Additionally, they participated in discussions by commenting on one issue.
joshklop: No activity this month.

bitwiseguy: This month, bitwiseguy focused on maintaining the deployment tooling, with their primary contribution being the support for the `op-contracts/v5.0.0-rc.2` upgrade in the `op-deployer` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18154). They also fixed related test timeouts in the CLI runner via PR ethereum-optimism/optimism#18179. In addition to their own changes, they actively supported the team by providing 8 code reviews. This work shows a primary focus on bug fixes and testing within the deployment process.

pcw109550: Focused on node synchronization within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, proposing a significant Proof of Concept for a "Light CL" in `op-node` (optimism#18196). In support of this effort, they identified and created three issues related to node syncing and potential bugs (#18124, #18125, #18126). While their primary development work was on this open PR, they also actively supported the team by conducting 14 code reviews. Their code changes, which modified 34 files, were primarily focused on bug fixes and tests.

sebastianst: Focused on significant refactoring and modularization within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository to improve its core architecture. They led this effort by moving fork names into a new package (#18121) and relocating package predeploys (#18145), both substantial architectural changes. Alongside this refactoring, sebastianst also fixed a configuration loading bug in the batch decoder (#18209) and actively supported the team by providing 17 code reviews.

smartcontracts: Focused on improving CI processes and contributing to future design this month, merging a pull request to enhance upgrade tests in CI (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18133). They also authored a significant design document for OPCM v2 (ethereum-optimism/design-docs#353) and were highly engaged in supporting the team's work, providing 30 code reviews. Their contributions show a focus on development infrastructure, design, and team collaboration.
geoknee: Contributed by reviewing and approving one pull request.

maurelian: This month, maurelian focused on development tooling and new features, merging a PR to optimize the build process in `op-deployers` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18130). They also proposed a new `DeployFeesDepositor` script (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18223) and provided significant team support by conducting 16 code reviews. Based on their code changes, their work was primarily centered on feature development and testing.

mds1: Focused on CI and deployment pipeline maintenance this month, merging 6 small PRs to address bugs and configuration issues. Their contributions included updating CLI flags for the op-deployer (optimism#18143) and renaming CI jobs to align with required checks (optimism#18139). In addition to their own fixes, mds1 was an active collaborator, providing 19 code reviews for teammates. This activity shows a primary focus on bug fixes and configuration changes to ensure system stability.

aliersh: Focused on repository maintenance and developer experience, merging three pull requests this month. Their most impactful contribution was a refactor in ethereum-optimism/optimism#18212 that removed a 157-line script, simplifying the codebase. They also improved repository organization by moving specifications in ethereum-optimism/specs#851 and enhanced CI guidance for developers in ethereum-optimism/optimism#18127. This work, along with 5 code reviews, demonstrates a focus on refactoring and bug fixes, with changes primarily affecting test files.
Inphi: No activity this month.

nonsense: Focused on improving the reliability and efficiency of the Optimism stack, merging four pull requests across multiple repositories. Their most impactful contributions included restricting the transaction mempool to trusted peers in `ethereum-optimism/op-geth#719` and executing a significant refactor of the `op-batcher` in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#18174`. JosepBove: Focused on operational maintenance in the `ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops` repository, merging two PRs to update an RPC configuration and apply a bugfix for betanets (#1281, #1280).
